protocol_name: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
protocol_name_html: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
description: Evolution has driven genetic diversity of life on Earth, but also created highly complex genomes that are difficult to sequence. Current draft genomes can have thousands to hundreds of thousands of contigs rather than chromosomes, containing incorrect assemblies, gaps and errors. With rapid advances in long-read technologies, it is becoming possible to resolve complex genomes, including repetitive, polyploid plant genomes. Despite the technology being available, a challenge persists: the extraction of pure high molecular weight DNA suitable for long-read sequencing. This is particularly true of recalcitrant native Australian trees such as Eucalypts and Acacias. To resolve this, firstly we optimised a density gradient and detergent based nuclei extraction to limit reads from high copy count plastid genomes. Secondly, we optimised a gentle high molecular weight DNA extraction free of columns and high centrifugation, to limit DNA fragmentation. Finally, the DNA was purified and size selected by gel electrophoresis. For sequencing, we adopted the portable MinION sequencer from Oxford Nanopore Technologies. Using these approaches, we have been obtaining >9 gigabases of sequencing from a single MinION flowcell, including reads over 100 kb in length. Such ultra-long reads assist the assembly of high quality genomes, from telomere to telomere.
before_start:
This protocol is designed for two sample nuclei isolations and DNA extractions, although upscaling is possible. Prepare the following for two samples:

 

  • Autoclave x2 500 mL Nalgene bottles, x10 1 L Schott bottles, x2 beakers and x2 funnels.
  • Collect a branch of Eucalyptus leaves, harvest and wash leaves with tap water.
  • Weigh 50 g of leaves into 50 g takeaway containers.
  • Pre-chill the blender in 4°C cold room.
  • For two sample extractions, on the day prepare 1 L nuclei isolation buﬀer and 1 L of nuclei wash buﬀer, and cool both down to 4°C.
  • Prepare lysis buffer fresh on the day of use.
  • Prepare all other solutions as listed below, storing at room temperature until use.

 

 

Nuclei isolation buffer (1 L for two samples)

 

  • Adjust to pH 6 (add HCl; estimate listed below).
  • Cool down to 4°C

Lysis buffer (10 mL per sample)

 

  • Prepare a fresh solution for optimal results. The solution should be clear before use.

 

Component

[Stock]

2% Sera-Mag beads solution (10 mL stock)

 

  • Sera-Mag SpeedBead magnetic carboxylate modified particles (Thermo Scientific 65152105050250).
  • Store at 4°C for up to 6 months.
  • First prepare buffer without the beads. Let the Sera-Mag beads come to room temperature.

 

Component

[Stock]

Quantity (10 mL)

18% Polyethylene glycol (PEG) 8,000

25%

50 µL

-

430 µL

 

  • Homogenise Sera-Mag beads thoroughly by shaking and swirling.
  • Prepare 2% Sera-Mag beads (200 µL for 10 mL buffer) by washing 4 times with water to remove sodium azide. Magnetise, remove supernatant, add ~500 µL H2O, flick tube, magnetise etc.
  • Resuspend the clean Sera-Mag beads in the buffer prepared.
  • Note: Potentially, AMPURE XP (Beckman Coulter) can be used but they must be washed 4 times with water and resuspended in their initial buffer.

 

 

Binding buffer solution (10 mL per sample)

 

  • 2 g of PEG 8,000 (or 8 mL of 25% stock) [final = 20%]
  • 75 g of sodium chloride [final = 3 M]
  • Adjust to 10 mL with molecular biology grade water (approx 2 mL).

 

Mix until the solution becomes clear. If PEG8000 is not dissolved, it can lead to a poor yield as PEG 8000 makes gDNA to bind to the beads.

 

 

Other solutions

 

  • Triton X-100 (ideally 10% solution)
  • Ethanol (100% and 70%)
  • RNAse A (e.g. 20 mg/mL Invitrogen PureLink)
  • 5 M Potassium acetate

 

 

Special equipment (for two samples)

 

  • 500 mL Nalgene bottle (x2)
  • 1 L Schott bottles (x10)
  • Beakers (x2)
  • Funnel (preferably glass) (x2)
  • Large Fine hair paint brushes (x2) (e.g. J.Burrows Mop Goat Hair 24 #9341694325125)
  • Magnetic Rack (for Falcon and Eppendorf tubes)
  • 15 mL Falcon tubes
  • 50 mL Falcon tubes
  • DNA LoBind Eppendorf tubes (e.g. 022431021)
  • Sieve or mesh, 300 µm (e.g. Kartell disk membrane; ART 844)
  • Miracloth or stretcher sheets (e.g Drager 334201)
  • 200 µL wide-bore pipette tips (e.g. Vertex 4290-00)

groups.group_name: MinION user group for high molecular weight DNA extraction from all kingdoms

authors_list.name: Ashley Jones

authors_list.name: Justin Borevitz
authors_list.affiliation: Research School of Biology, Australian National University. Canberra, ACT Australia.

guidelines:
This protocol is a modified and optimised combination of the following two publications. When citing, please also note the original publications below.

 

Bolger et al. (2014). The genome of the stress-tolerant wild tomato species Solanum pennellii. Nature Genetics 46, 1034.

 

Mayjonade et al. (2016). Extraction of high-molecular-weight genomic DNA for long-read sequencing of single molecules. BioTechniques 61, 203-205.

 

Eucalyptus tissue used in this protocol was kindly provided by the Australian National Botanic Gardens, Canberra, Australia.

components.data: Place 50 g of leaves into a blender with enough nuclei isolation buffer to cover the blades (approximately 150 mL).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place 50 g of leaves into a blender with enough nuclei isolation buffer to cover the blades (approximately 150 mL).

components.name: Section

source_data.annotation: Optimised for Eucalyptus, a diploid ~500 Mb genome. Larger genomes or polyploid plants can have less input accordingly.
source_data.thread_text: Optimised for Eucalyptus, a diploid ~500 Mb genome. Larger genomes or polyploid plants can have less input accordingly.
source_data.body: Optimised for Eucalyptus, a diploid ~500 Mb genome. Larger genomes or polyploid plants can have less input accordingly.

components.data: Homogenise the tissue on max speed. Transfer to a beaker, repeatedly washing out blender with nuclei isolation buffer (500 mL buffer is allocated per extraction).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Homogenise the tissue on max speed. Transfer to a beaker, repeatedly washing out blender with nuclei isolation buffer (500 mL buffer is allocated per extraction).

components.data: Clean the blender with tap water, 70% ethanol and then MQW; process the other sample (repeating steps 1 and 2).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Clean the blender with tap water, 70% ethanol and then MQW; process the other sample (repeating steps 1 and 2).

components.data: FILTRATION (ideally 4°C cold room)
components.name: Section

components.data: Filter homogenate using a sieve (or disk membrane mesh placed in a funnel) into a 1 L Schott bottle. Forcibly squeeze out as much residual homogenate from the leaf debris as possible, maximising nuclei capture.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Filter homogenate using a sieve (or disk membrane mesh placed in a funnel) into a 1 L Schott bottle. Forcibly squeeze out as much residual homogenate from the leaf debris as possible, maximising nuclei capture.

components.data: Filter homogenate through 1 layer of Miracloth using a funnel and 1 L Schott bottle. Gently squeeze residual homogenate through the Miracloth.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Filter homogenate through 1 layer of Miracloth using a funnel and 1 L Schott bottle. Gently squeeze residual homogenate through the Miracloth.

source_data.annotation: May need to change the layer half way through (very dirty and clogged).
source_data.thread_text: May need to change the layer half way through (very dirty and clogged).
source_data.body: May need to change the layer half way through (very dirty and clogged).

components.data: Repeat Filtration through 2 layers of Miracloth then 4 layers (using new Schott bottles).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Repeat Filtration through 2 layers of Miracloth then 4 layers (using new Schott bottles).

components.data: Finally, gravity filter through 8 layers of Miracloth (no squeezing) into a 500 mL Nalgene bottle. Repeat steps 4-6 for the second sample.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Finally, gravity filter through 8 layers of Miracloth (no squeezing) into a 500 mL Nalgene bottle. Repeat steps 4-6 for the second sample.

components.data: Add 2.5 mL of 100% Triton X-100, or 25 mL of 10% (final concentration 0.5%).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 2.5 mL of 100% Triton X-100, or 25 mL of 10% (final concentration 0.5%).

components.data: NUCLEI ISOLATION
components.name: Section

components.data: Incubate mixture on an ice bath with gentle rocking for 30 min.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Incubate mixture on an ice bath with gentle rocking for 30 min.

components.data: Discard the supernatant and add 200 mL of nuclei wash buffer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Discard the supernatant and add 200 mL of nuclei wash buffer.

components.data: Gently resuspend the pellet using a large fine hair paint brush, soaked in freshly made pre-chilled nuclei wash buffer.
components.name: Description

components.data: Discard supernatant and repeat with another 200 mL of nuclei wash buffer. The pellet should become grey-white with no traces of green. If not, make more nuclei wash buffer and repeat the resuspending and washing steps.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Discard supernatant and repeat with another 200 mL of nuclei wash buffer. The pellet should become grey-white with no traces of green. If not, make more nuclei wash buffer and repeat the resuspending and washing steps.

source_data.thread_text: 1 L of nuclei wash buffer is suitable for x2 samples to be washed x2 times with 200 mL each, then a final resuspension with 100 mL each.
source_data.body: 1 L of nuclei wash buffer is suitable for x2 samples to be washed x2 times with 200 mL each, then a final resuspension with 100 mL each.

components.data: After the final spin down, discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellet with 50 mL of nuclei wash buffer. Transfer evenly across two 50 mL Falcon tubes. Repeat the resuspension with another 50 mL of buffer and add to the two Falcon tubes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After the final spin down, discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellet with 50 mL of nuclei wash buffer. Transfer evenly across two 50 mL Falcon tubes. Repeat the resuspension with another 50 mL of buffer and add to the two Falcon tubes.

components.data: Centrifuge at 600 rcf and 4°C for 30 minutes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Centrifuge at 600 rcf and 4°C for 30 minutes.

components.data: Discard the supernatant. The nuclei pellets can now be stored -80°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Discard the supernatant. The nuclei pellets can now be stored -80°C.

components.data: DNA EXTRACTION FROM NUCLEI
components.name: Section

components.data: Prepare 10 mL of fresh lysis buffer per sample. Ideally, pre-heat at 50-65°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.annotation: Therefore, the SDS will be approximately 2% final concentration. Usually just one of the two Falcon tubes of a nuclei prep per sample are used.

source_data.body: Therefore, the SDS will be approximately 2% final concentration. Usually just one of the two Falcon tubes of a nuclei prep per sample are used.

components.data: Add 200 µL of RNAse A to each sample (20 mg/mL Invitrogen PureLink).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 200 µL of RNAse A to each sample (20 mg/mL Invitrogen PureLink).

components.data: Incubate the samples at 50-60°C for 1 h, shaking at 400 - 900 rpm if possible.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Incubate the samples at 50-60°C for 1 h, shaking at 400 - 900 rpm if possible.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 22 of Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name_html: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.annotation: Higher temperatures and longer incubations lead to DNA damage.
source_data.thread_text: Higher temperatures and longer incubations lead to DNA damage.
source_data.body: Higher temperatures and longer incubations lead to DNA damage.

components.data: Add 1/3 volume of 5 M Potassium Acetate and mix by inverting to precipitate the proteins and the polysaccharides that will complex with SDS.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 1/3 volume of 5 M Potassium Acetate and mix by inverting to precipitate the proteins and the polysaccharides that will complex with SDS.

components.data: Incubate on ice (4°C) for 10 min (don’t rotate, DNA vulnerable).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Incubate on ice (4°C) for 10 min (don’t rotate, DNA vulnerable).

components.data: Centrifuge at 5,000 rcf for 5 min at 4°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Centrifuge at 5,000 rcf for 5 min at 4°C.

components.data: Transfer supernatant to a new tube, centrifuge again at 5,000 rcf for 10 min at 4°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer supernatant to a new tube, centrifuge again at 5,000 rcf for 10 min at 4°C.

components.data: Transfer to a new tube and add 1.2x binding buffer. Ideally, split across x2 15 mL Falcon tubes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer to a new tube and add 1.2x binding buffer. Ideally, split across x2 15 mL Falcon tubes.

components.data: Add 1 mL of 2% Sera-Mag beads (500 µL per Falcon tube if split).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 1 mL of 2% Sera-Mag beads (500 µL per Falcon tube if split).

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 28 of Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name_html: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.annotation: Beads are in excess and could be reduced.
source_data.thread_text: Beads are in excess and could be reduced.
source_data.body: Beads are in excess and could be reduced.

components.data: Mix by inverting the tube 20 times. Incubate with gentle agitation using a rotator or a rocker platform for 15 min at room temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Mix by inverting the tube 20 times. Incubate with gentle agitation using a rotator or a rocker platform for 15 min at room temperature.

components.data: Place the tube in a magnetic rack for 30 min or more (until the solution becomes clear, can be over an hour).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the tube in a magnetic rack for 30 min or more (until the solution becomes clear, can be over an hour).

components.data: Remove the supernatant without disturbing the beads.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove the supernatant without disturbing the beads.

components.data: Wash the beads by filling the tube with 70% ethanol, let beads settle if disturbed, and pour out ethanol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Wash the beads by filling the tube with 70% ethanol, let beads settle if disturbed, and pour out ethanol.

components.data: Repeat the ethanol wash another 3-5 times, until satisfied the beads are clean.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Repeat the ethanol wash another 3-5 times, until satisfied the beads are clean.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 33 of Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name_html: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.annotation: If the beads are very dirty, remove the tube from the magnetic rack, resuspend beads by flicking the tube, magnetise until clear, remove supernatant, repeat washing.
source_data.thread_text: If the beads are very dirty, remove the tube from the magnetic rack, resuspend beads by flicking the tube, magnetise until clear, remove supernatant, repeat washing.
source_data.body: If the beads are very dirty, remove the tube from the magnetic rack, resuspend beads by flicking the tube, magnetise until clear, remove supernatant, repeat washing.

components.data: Transfer the beads to an Eppendorf tube. This can be done in a series of small volume ethanol washes that resuspend the beads, transfer to Eppendorf tube, then place on the magnetic rack, remove supernatant and repeat into the same tube.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer the beads to an Eppendorf tube. This can be done in a series of small volume ethanol washes that resuspend the beads, transfer to Eppendorf tube, then place on the magnetic rack, remove supernatant and repeat into the same tube.

components.data: Remove all traces of ethanol, and let the beads air dry for 1-4 min. Do not let the beads dry completely, they will crack and significantly reduce DNA recovery.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove all traces of ethanol, and let the beads air dry for 1-4 min. Do not let the beads dry completely, they will crack and significantly reduce DNA recovery.

components.data: Using a wide-bore pipette tip, add 220 µL of ultra-pure H2O to the beads, gently resuspending. Gently tapping the tube is also suitable.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using a wide-bore pipette tip, add 220 µL of ultra-pure H2O to the beads, gently resuspending. Gently tapping the tube is also suitable.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 36 of Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name_html: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.annotation: Larger volume based on PippinHT input across x1 whole cassette.
source_data.thread_text: Larger volume based on PippinHT input across x1 whole cassette.
source_data.body: Larger volume based on PippinHT input across x1 whole cassette.

components.data: Transfer 200 µL of supernatant (contains DNA) to a new tube, avoiding any carry-over of beads.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer 200 µL of supernatant (contains DNA) to a new tube, avoiding any carry-over of beads.

components.data: Place the tubes in the magnetic rack for ~30 min. Let the solution become clear.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the tubes in the magnetic rack for ~30 min. Let the solution become clear.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 37 of Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name_html: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.annotation: Highly concentrated DNA will take a long time. The tube can be left on the magnetic rack overnight, or add more water.
source_data.thread_text: Highly concentrated DNA will take a long time. The tube can be left on the magnetic rack overnight, or add more water.
source_data.body: Highly concentrated DNA will take a long time. The tube can be left on the magnetic rack overnight, or add more water.

components.data: For some species, the DNA may be pure enough for sequencing at this point. However, for most recalcitrant plants, the DNA will still have impurities and DNA fragmentation is inevitable. Gel purification is an ideal solution to both problems.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: For some species, the DNA may be pure enough for sequencing at this point. However, for most recalcitrant plants, the DNA will still have impurities and DNA fragmentation is inevitable. Gel purification is an ideal solution to both problems.

components.data: GEL PURIFICATION: PIPPIN PREP
components.name: Section

components.data: Using a PippinHT (Sage Science) or similar automated electrophoresis product, gel purify approximately 30 µg, following the manufacturer’s instructions. A 15 kb high pass separation is recommended, however if DNA is plentiful, 20 kb high pass is more suitable. The PippinHT has 12 lanes, however a lane pair needs be dedicated to an external ladder, leaving 10 lanes for samples. 20 µL of DNA goes into each lane (therefore 200 µL elution in previous section). The manufacturer recommends a maximum 1.5 µg per lane (15 µg total per cassette), however, can be successfully overloaded to 3 µg per lane (perhaps more). The size selection will not be as precise, but is of no concern here.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using a PippinHT (Sage Science) or similar automated electrophoresis product, gel purify approximately 30 µg, following the manufacturer’s instructions. A 15 kb high pass separation is recommended, however if DNA is plentiful, 20 kb high pass is more suitable. The PippinHT has 12 lanes, however a lane pair needs be dedicated to an external ladder, leaving 10 lanes for samples. 20 µL of DNA goes into each lane (therefore 200 µL elution in previous section). The manufacturer recommends a maximum 1.5 µg per lane (15 µg total per cassette), however, can be successfully overloaded to 3 µg per lane (perhaps more). The size selection will not be as precise, but is of no concern here.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 40 of Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.protocol_name_html: Nuclear DNA purification from recalcitrant plant species for long-read sequencing
source_data.annotation: Alternatively, a chloroform: isoamyl alcohol 24:1 clean-up can be performed to remove residual phenols and proteins. Other possibilities (untested), are digestion with proteinase K and another bead clean up. Also would be interesting to experiment with adding PVP to the binding buffer to further reduce polyphenols.
source_data.thread_text: Alternatively, a chloroform: isoamyl alcohol 24:1 clean-up can be performed to remove residual phenols and proteins. Other possibilities (untested), are digestion with proteinase K and another bead clean up. Also would be interesting to experiment with adding PVP to the binding buffer to further reduce polyphenols.
source_data.body: Alternatively, a chloroform: isoamyl alcohol 24:1 clean-up can be performed to remove residual phenols and proteins. Other possibilities (untested), are digestion with proteinase K and another bead clean up. Also would be interesting to experiment with adding PVP to the binding buffer to further reduce polyphenols.

components.data: After separation, wait at least 45 min (hours or overnight is suitable), to aid elution and recovery.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After separation, wait at least 45 min (hours or overnight is suitable), to aid elution and recovery.

components.data: Collect the contents of all elution wells into a DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube (approx. 300 µL).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Collect the contents of all elution wells into a DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube (approx. 300 µL).

components.data: Add 30 µL of 0.1% tween solution to each elution well (provided in kit). Wait at least 10 min and then transfer the contents to the same DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube (another 300 µL, tube total is approx. 600 µL).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 30 µL of 0.1% tween solution to each elution well (provided in kit). Wait at least 10 min and then transfer the contents to the same DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube (another 300 µL, tube total is approx. 600 µL).

components.data: Add 1.2x binding buffer (approx. 720 µL), and 100 µL of 2% Sera-Mag beads to the DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube. Incubate, magnetise and ethanol wash as previously described in ‘DNA extraction from nuclei’.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 1.2x binding buffer (approx. 720 µL), and 100 µL of 2% Sera-Mag beads to the DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube. Incubate, magnetise and ethanol wash as previously described in ‘DNA extraction from nuclei’.

components.data: After drying the beads elute with 65 µL of ultra-pure water. Incubate, magnetise and transfer to a new DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube using a wide-bore pipette tip. Expect 20-30% recovery relative to total input (~6-9 µg).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After drying the beads elute with 65 µL of ultra-pure water. Incubate, magnetise and transfer to a new DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube using a wide-bore pipette tip. Expect 20-30% recovery relative to total input (~6-9 µg).

components.data: SEQUENCING LIBRARY PREPARATION
components.name: Section

components.data:
For sequencing, we adopted the portable MinION sequencer from Oxford Nanopore Technologies. There are two native genomic DNA library preparations available; a rapid transposase based method (SQK-RAD004) and ligation based method (SQK-LSK108 /109). Following the manufacturer’s instructions, prepare a library and load the MinION for sequencing. Note that Oxford Nanopore recommends a mass of DNA optimised for 0.2 pmol (193 fmol). However, this is based on an average length of 8 kb. Therefore, the amount of input DNA needs to be adjusted. The following is recommended based on PippinHT size selection:

 

Fragment sizes

Rapid SQK-RAD004

Ligation SQK-LSK108 /109

No size selection, ~8 kb

400 ng

1,000 ng

15 kb high pass

800 ng

3,000 ng

20 kb high pass

1,000 ng

4,000 ng
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
For sequencing, we adopted the portable MinION sequencer from Oxford Nanopore Technologies. There are two native genomic DNA library preparations available; a rapid transposase based method (SQK-RAD004) and ligation based method (SQK-LSK108 /109). Following the manufacturer’s instructions, prepare a library and load the MinION for sequencing. Note that Oxford Nanopore recommends a mass of DNA optimised for 0.2 pmol (193 fmol). However, this is based on an average length of 8 kb. Therefore, the amount of input DNA needs to be adjusted. The following is recommended based on PippinHT size selection:

 

Fragment sizes

Rapid SQK-RAD004

Ligation SQK-LSK108 /109

No size selection, ~8 kb

400 ng

1,000 ng

15 kb high pass

4,000 ng

components.data: Using the protocol described, we have been obtaining clean high molecular weight DNA (Figure 1, Table 1). DNA fragment size has been predominantly 20-140 kb in length (Figure 2). During sequencing, we have been obtaining >9 gigabases from a single MinION flowcell for recalcitrant Eucalyptus species, including reads over 100 kb in length (Table 2, Figure 3).
components.name: Expected result

source_data.result: Using the protocol described, we have been obtaining clean high molecular weight DNA (Figure 1, Table 1). DNA fragment size has been predominantly 20-140 kb in length (Figure 2). During sequencing, we have been obtaining >9 gigabases from a single MinION flowcell for recalcitrant Eucalyptus species, including reads over 100 kb in length (Table 2, Figure 3).
